course.title: Unreal Engine C++ Developer: Learn C++ and Make Video Games
course.subtitle: Created in collaboration with Epic Games. Learn C++ from basics while making your first 4 video games in Unreal

reviews.body: Great course, i enjoyed each section. A big advantage of this couse is that you start practicing right away, by creating 5 different games. Thank you!

review is splitted into 3 sections:

first part: really slow but unreal concepts are being passed in engaging and it's well explained.

2nd part:

some parts were ok but widget part was seriously horrible just repeat blindly w/o understanding which really pissed me off. his heavy english accent, you can extrapolate useful info there but seriously it's like that person didn't know what was going on in the lectures beforehand and assumed we're blueprint wizards right away....

3rd part - if it was only that instructor i'd give a better rating.

excellent explains everything and actually that project is cool!

The courses were great and super fun. Sam's course at the end was my favorite going in depth and making a really cool game. Very happy with this course. Some basic C++ will help anyone that is doing this class.

Wonderful beginner course. There are a few things that were in the archived material that I miss going into this one; however, this course gives enough foundation to fill in the blanks. The one thing that is really missing for someone just starting is the foundations of C++. I have taken C++ separately and still find that moving into UE4 with C++ some of the later concepts about casting are - I can do it but I stumble and don;t understand why or how it works when it works.

One of the better Unreal courses by far! I bought this course when it originally released. I never completed it before (nothing to do with the quality of the first iteration, I was really enjoying the content, just had school and work tearing me apart and I fell off) but recently I started coding again and took the semester off so I decided to go back through it. I already knew my way around Unreal a little bit before starting, but I take every chance I get to try and learn more, and you guys managed to teach me more.

I've made it through a few other courses before and they're never really informative ("Alright, this is how you do this, this, and this. Give this thing a value of 5.f. Now call ThisFunctionYouWouldHaveNeverBeenAbleToFigureOut, make sure to include its header 'YadaYada/GoodLuckWhenYoureOnyourOwn.h'. Okay, great. Let me show you something else now.") You guys really did a great job actually teaching instead of showing how to just copy code. I really love that there's almost always a challenge in each lecture, and that's honestly the thing that no one else seems to do. Now I'm super excited to meet back up with Michael to do his Blender course that I bought years ago as well. Cheers, guys!

Fantastic course. The updates have really improved the quality of the course significantly. The final section in particular is truly incredible work and leaves you with a piece of work you can feel proud of. The middle sections(section 4 and 5 in particular) could use some work, but as they are actively being updated to improve their shortcomings I'm sure this course will only become closer and closer to perfect with time.

The course has taught me every basics of the Engine and its features as well as programming in C++.

Edit: As mentioned before I'm very sad that I didn't have to see Ben teaching in the updated version of the course. He was the one who explained to me all the basic things that I was struggling with. After that I went through the whole updated course, but because Ben has taught me everything I needed to understand the concept of the Engine I had no problem to do all the challenges by myself. Also shout out to Sam Pattuzzi for also good presentations.
The course is amazing, the only downside is the Toon Tanks section which needs more work in my opinion. The instructor teaches way too fast which causes a lot of frustration in new students.

A very solid course that introduces the student to the basic UE4 game engine concepts. The only thing that would make it better is a one more advanced section at the end of the course. Besides that, if you're a beginner and would like to learn the basics of UE4 - this is the course for you!

So I came to this course as a newbie, wanted to start learning C++ and Making Games (it's written in the title) so I was really excited.

The first section is for very basic things to C++ and it's good, if you at least saw some code before (no matter what prog. language it was) otherwise it's a little bit challenging to come into it, but that's fine, nobody tells that it should be easy.

But after the first section troubles start appearing one by one.

First of all there is not enough information given about C++, and all the mechanics that a person really should understand to make anything that's going on on the screen, and personally I didn't get enough explanations. I watched some of the video 3+ times and it didn't work. But that's fine, I just bought another pure C++ course in order to understand.

- You really need to do this, learn C++ somewhere else. If you reckon to learn C++ here at this course, forget it, you need another one.

From that problem goes another one, when you don't understand what's going on you start skipping all those challenges, because you cannot manage them simply because there were not enough knowledge given.

The section with the dungeon, where the main mechanic we're working on for sure is interesting, but it's explained too long for the things that could be explained much faster and easier, as it was in other courses I took.

Then we move to the section with Toon Tank which was just awful. At least because we came here to learn C++ and not Blueprints, the half of all that was done there, was done in blueprints, which are not introduced so well in this course. So I made a pause after that section, Cause I was skipping the challenges and started just copying and it's not a good studying process. So until this moment I haven't learnt anything essential.

Then I took a break, learn C++ separately and took another Unreal Engine 4 course not related to this one. And came back to finish this one, I had only Simple Shooter section left.

And Simple Shooter is the only reason I put 2 stars here, and not 1.

So the only really cool section in this course is Simple Shooter.

Which you can NOT go through if you are not familliar with C++, and Unreal Engine already. So I managed all the challenges in this section and in general it's fine and interesting to go through.

So if you're considering to buy this course and think that you'll achieve both C++ and Unreal Engine, and it can give you a good start, no it won't.

As a conclusion: This course starts well, but then you face struggling and frustrate a lot.

You cannot go through it, if don't have additional knowledge.

The only reason to buy it is as addition to some other more consistent and substantive courses you might learn.

This was a very interesting course. I've learned a lot of things during this time. The ToonTanks section needs a complete rework. I was just following the instructor blindly without knowing why was he doing it that way. It was really frustrating to complete that section.

I had this course years ago but since i'm a Unity guy i couldn't complete it. But my current work requires Unreal and i needed to find a decent Unreal course which provides C++ foundations of Unreal Engine. There are really a small number of C++ courses on the web. Unreal documentation and the community just don't exist at all. So, this course provides a great detail on that matter. This course can be accepted as a beginner friendly but Unreal IS NOT a begginer friendly engine. So, i strongly recommend everyone to practice basic understanding of a simpler game engine (like Unity or Godot) before starting with Unreal. Unreal may seems easier with all the blueprint stuff but it isn't.

The toon tank section was the greatest part of the course i don't know why everyone is so upset about it. It was the only part where i feel like i was doing some coding. The TPS was also great. The behaviour tree sections are gold. Because it is not easy to find a C++ implementation on those topics. But TPS felt rushed towards the end. Bulls & Cows is terrible i'm sorry but it is. I'm also a teacher and i believe you can find a more interesting topic than that. I just watched it to get my certificate. Building escape can be reduced to 2 hours at most. I like the pacing of the toon tanks section. I never wanted to start the arhieved course since it is 60 hours long so, the revision is nearly perfect in my opinion. Just replace the bull&cow game with something else that game is not interesting at all.

Thanks everyone who contributed in creation of this course. We love you.

instructor.name: Ben Tristem
instructor.briefIntroduction:
Hi, I'm Ben. I have a degree in computing from Imperial College London, and a physics diploma from the Open University. 

I started working for myself at the age of 15, and never looked back. I explored careers as varied as being a commercial pilot, stunt-man, rock climbing instructor, and more. None of these provided a continued challenge, and stable income in the same way technology does. 

After building and selling a home computer support business, I became an angel investor and business mentor here in Cambridge UK. I fell in love with teaching game development through one of my investments, and I now spend all of my time sharing my passion with people like you. 

I can't wait to help you experience the fulfilment, and financial freedom, that having a deep understanding of technology brings. 

So why not start learning to make games with me and my team now?

See you soon! 

Ben
